name.value: El frutal: El juego de cartas
Il Frutteto: Il gioco di carte
Le Verger: Le jeu de cartes

item.description:
Will the players have harvested all the fruit before the raven reaches the orchard?

A co-operative game for 1-6 players.

Contents:
1 wooden raven marker
1 six sided die
40 fruit cards
9 path cards
1 orchard card
6 basket card
set of game instructions

In the center of the game area, arrange the nine path cards to form a straight path to the orchard card on the end. Place the wooden raven on the first card. Each player takes a basket and places it in front of them. Sort the fruit cards and place them in separate piles next to the game area.

Each player rolls the 6 sided die:


 Red, yellow, green or blue:
 Take a card showing the fruit of the corresponding color and place it on your basket. If there is no suitable fruit left, nothing happens
 
 The basket:
 Take any two pieces of fruit from the piles and place them in your basket.
 
 The raven:
 The raven marker moves once space closer to the orchard.
 


If the players harvest all the fruits before the raven reaches the orchard, everyone wins. If the raven reaches the orchard first, everyone loses.

name.value: C'è chi scende e c'è chi sale

item.description:
Whoever, after a couple of Ups and Downs is the first to reach pink sheep Rosemary, wins the game.

A classic competition race for 2-4 players.

Travel games:
• Popular classic games in a suitcase
• Ideal for long journeys by car, train or airplane
• Magnetic game figures: nothing lost between the seats!
• Game board inside lid
• Suitcase is the packaging

After ´Balderdash´ and ´Beyond Balderdash´, comes ´More Beyond Balderdash´ (Más Absolutas Idioteces). This game is the third edition in the series and it´s all in Spanish.

The game is based on bluffing your opponents into guessing your false definitions to obscure words. The real answers are often even more outrageous than the bluffs, so the game offers plenty of laughs.


From Spanish publisher:

Más Absolutas Idioteces es un juego absolutamente divertido donde podrás farolear delante de tus adversarios para intentar convencerles de que tu respuesta es la correcta.

El juego contiene preguntas de la vida cotidiana que nos hacemos todos los días y nunca nos preguntamos por su respuesta o de dónde vienen.

Esta nueva versión contiene una nueva categoría especial de misterios de la vida sin solución… todo queda en manos de tu poder de convicción.

Contenido:

- 960 preguntas en 320 tarjetas
- 1 bloc de anotación
- 6 cartones porta tarjetas
- 42 fichas de puntuación
- Instrucciones
- 1 dado

item.description:
Lion, Lisa, London – Who is quick at finding words with the letter being searched for?

A bewitching word game collection for 2-8 players ages Ages 7 and up.

Wiggling cow Elsa stands on a large heap of grass bales. Try to loosen the bales with the hay fork from the heap and carefully pull them out and off the game board. Watch out! Elsa must not fall over. The aim of the game is to collect the most bales of grass without tipping Elsa the cow.

A curious game of skill for 1-4 players.

item.description: How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party.

item.description:
Early dice based football game. Has only 4 types of plays that may be run; Forward Pass, Line Buck, Trick Play and Kick.

Uses 7 custom dice, 4 for the offensive player 3 for the defense. After rolling you look up the result on a chart.

See the words! Match the pictures! Ring the bell! Everyone wins!
A new version of the hit game I Spy Eagle Eye, scaled to suit the youngest I Spy fans.

4 levels of play

Helps develop language skills, word association, matching like and similar objects and social skills

For the speedy spy on the go! Just flip 5 picture tokens and search for matches. With pictures on both sides, it's never the same game twice!

The first player to win 5 rounds is the game winner.

Easily portable box makes this a great travel game!

4 versions of play
Helps develop observation, dexterity and social skills

It takes a keen eye and a quick hand to keep up in this fast-paced matching game.

Search the colorful picture cards to find the one that matches the silhouette card in hand.

Player with the most matches wins!

4 levels of play

Helps develop visual discrimination, critical thinking and social skills

Be the dinosaur hunter to find the most matching pairs! But be observant...the matches aren't exact. Flip the tokens as you play to make a constantly changing game.

The better you know your dinos, the faster you'll be. The game comes with a guide to the featured creatures.

Handy, portable box makes this a great game to take on trips.

3 ways to play
Develops observation, memory and matching skills

Become an I Spy Private Eye.....can you remember what you spy? Shake up the cubes,press the timer and go! You have 30 seconds to spy the I Spy images on all 9-picture cubes before they are hidden from view. "Beep,Beep!"...times up! Examine the evidence. Choose one I Spy picture card and find all the images that match the cubes and score points....but watch out for a challenge!

name.value: I Spy Memory Game: Travel Edition

item.description:
Your favorite I Spy Memory Game in a take-along, travel-size version. All new cards for new memory and matching fun! Made your matches? Now solve the 5 new riddles.

The game uses the classic I Spy photography of Walter Wick as the basis for two styles of play. Younger children can simply match the images on two different cards while older players can find the images that correspond to various riddles.

New riddles versus the full-sized edition, but only about a third as many tiles.

name.value: Animal Soup Game: There's Always One!

item.description: The kooky critters of Animal Soup love playing together in their silly soup bowl. But guess what? They love it even more when you find one-of-a-kind pictures of their friends so you can fish them out of the soup!

name.value: Green Eggs and Ham: Speedy Diner!

item.description:
The fast-paced frenetically fun food game

Sam-I-Am has opened a café and invited his friends, Fox, Mouse, and Goat, for dinner. Help serve up his signature green eggs and ham along with a menu full of other silly Seussian foods. Listen closely because these critter customers can’t decide what to eat! And hurry, hurry, hurry—the musical timer is playing and speedy service is the key to 5-star success!

In this fast-paced, frenetically fun game for preschoolers, players work together to deliver food to the café guests as fast as they can. Take turns being the Chef calling out orders to the other players, who serve as waiters, running back and forth to pick up the foods and deliver them to the correct customers. The faster you deliver the food, the more tips you’ll make! But watch out—when you hear “Bugs in the Kitchen!” you’ve got to race back to the dining room and check all the tables for insects. Players use color, shape and other pre-reading skills to identify food items and counting to collect their reward coins.

Inspired by the classic Dr. Seuss children’s story, Green Eggs & Ham - Speedy Diner! Game serves up big laughs and fast-action role-play fun. The whimsical Musical Menu Book helps kids make the association between letters and words, inspiring confidence and a love for reading.

name.value: Dr. Seuss: Oh the Places You'll Go! Game

item.description:
Your future is full of exciting possibilities! What will you do?

Take a wild adventure through life's twisty-turns and tough choices to discover a world of future possibilities. Along the way, try to guess what future your friends and family will choose!

The wise and whimsical book by Dr. Seuss comes to life in this playful game for all ages. The perfect gift for someone celebrating an important milestone—like graduating from grade school or moving to a new town—this game gets the whole family thinking about the future and all its wondrous possibilities.

name.value: Oh the Wondrous Places You'll Go! Travel Card Game

item.description:
Start imagining your wondrous journey!

Tickle your travel bug with this deck of cards describing 51½ wondrous places you can go! Each card features stunning photography, unbelievable facts, surprising history, and brain-twisting trivia about a multitude of amazing destinations.

Easy to store and tote, Oh the Wondrous Places You'll Go! Game is the perfect family entertainment for road trips, air travel, a rainy day—or for any time you're craving a little excitement. From famous landmarks to hidden gems, a world of adventure awaits!

Search the seashore for hidden treasures!

Hit the beach with your favorite monkey for a seashore scavenger hunt adventure! Flip a card to reveal your challenge. Then search for sea creatures and colorful treasures hidden below five secret beach locations. Can you find a match? But watch out for waves! If the game spinner lands on a wave, shake the box and the treasures will slide and hide in new locations. Find the most treasures to win!

The game of ball bouncing, dice tumbling, coin flipping fun!

You can be a neighborhood Super Helper just like Curious George! Volunteer at the firehouse, pitch in at the restaurant, or help tidy up at home. Flip over three cards to see who needs help. Chose where you want to help—at home, the firehouse, or the restaurant—then drop the ball, coin, or cube into the tower and try to make a match!

The bouncy ball, flippy coin, and dice cube tumble through the roof of the tower and magically come out on different sides. The player who helps the most wins the game.

Super Helper game prize stickers add to the fun!

name.value: Curious George: Hide and Seek Zoo Game

item.description:
The wild game of hiding, seeking, and zoo-keeping fun!

Your favorite monkey is in charge of the zoo and everything is going wild!

Grab your "walkie talkie" and get ready: The man with the yellow hat will be calling in to send you on exciting missions all over the zoo. Feed and care for zoo animals, repair fences, and clean up messes. But watch out—when you hear “THE ANIMALS HAVE ESCAPED,” it’s time to spring into action! The other players put on their animal masks and hide. It’s your job to find them. But hurry—the zoo must open on time!

Join Curious George for some playful problem-solving and up-on-your-feet hide-and-go-seek fun!

Available at Target, target.com, and specialty retail outlets.

The epic battle of Fire Bulls echoed the greatest counterback of Qi from annihilation in 279 B.C. In the game "Fire Bulls", players participate in the return of Qi with fury Fire Bulls driving Yen away from the peaceful land of Qi. Fire bulls are clothed with cape in marks of phantom, color of spirit and masked with faces of furious tiger and deadly knives. Thousands, running, rampaging with burning tail soaked in oil, fearless, driving violent but now horrified army of Yen, now running, scattering, crying, to the mean of end, the end of officious aggression. Yes, take them now and let it shall be the lesson from the ancient to the master of your hands.

The game components consists of Qi and Yen army cards, Qi army cards, most of them are Fire Bulls with various colors, forms the hands of each players. Yen army cards represents the victory points players needs to acquire to win the game and the benefit the player defeating this army card can earn. These army cards are represented as streams of retreating troops. Players take turns to either resupply Fire Bulls or attack the Yen army.

Now, the players will play the roles of Qi Generals and participate in this great war. Please the bulls you have to chase after and defeat the Yen army, and witness this glorious warfare in which the less conquers the more.

item.description:
In Majority, each player represents a political party in an unnamed parliament. There are 15 political issues represented by cards - each party has a platform of 10 that they are interested in passing bills about, with varying point values.

On each turn a player proposes a bill and attempts to get a majority for it - if this happens the parties interested in the issue score points. There are also event cards which can change the number of seats held by the parties, etc.

Contents:

 60 political platform cards
 50 event cards
 6 pawns
 1 game board
 1 die
 1 set of rules (in Dutch, French, and English)

Island Invasion is a simple game about the American invasion of Guam in World War II (the rules do not give the name of the island, but it is clearly Guam from the map, not to mention the publisher had an office there). The American player starts with 6 landing craft approaching the island, and must land them in the face of artillery and pillbox fire from the Japanese. Once the Americans have landed, the soldiers can capture each other.

Contents:

 14 plastic American soldiers
 14 plastic Japanese soldiers
 6 landing craft counters
 2 dice
 1 board
 1 set of English rules
 1 set of Japanese rules

From back of box (not a neutral description):

Backseat Drawing Junior brings the outrageous fun of Backseat Drawing to the entire family. Players race to identify a drawing done by the "artist" - but the artist doesn't know what he or she is drawing! It's up to the "director" to tell the artist how to draw the picture without giving away the name of the item shown on the picture card.

The laughter builds as the artist attempts to follow directions and everyone tries to identify the drawing. With Backseat Drawing Junior everyone can play and the fun never stops!

Re-implements: Backseat Drawing

The game again takes place in the Industrial Northeast as the owner of one of four major railroads. Your objective is to build westward and take advantage of resources that you may place along the way. You draw a set of tiles and use capital and resource tiles. The game takes place in three separate ages, a Silver, Golden and Rust age. VP are earned by the types of resources claimed by your company routes versus the age you are ending, VP for making it to Chicago, VP for each city you are connected to and VP for being a railroad built furthest to the west.

Resources degrade over time and resources and track rights are hotly contested throughout the game.

Manifest Railways can be found here:

http://www.jkntech.com/blog/page/Manifest-Railways-Board-Game.aspx

name.value: Scary Tales: Snow White vs. The Giant

item.description:
Snow White vs. The Giant is the second game in the Scary Tales series of two-player games pitting common fairy tale characters against each other. Here's more about the two characters in this game from the publisher:

"Fee, Fi, Fo, Fum...you don't want to mess with this chum. The Giant can crush his foes with his enormous strength, and he has his Magic Hen on his side, as well. But sly Snow White is no longer her sweet self, and she has some tricks up her sleeve, including the assistance of her Seven Dwarfs. Will the kingdom thrive under the rule of either of these challengers? A battle of enormous proportions awaits!"

The setting for Scary Tales is a kingdom, where a battle awaits as the king has died, leaving no heir. While the enchanted forest is feared and the castle is covered in dark clouds, corruption has affected the town and only those with the utmost abilities in Strength, Wisdom, Magic and Luck will be able to collect enough relics from the stories of long ago to prove themselves worthy of being the new leader. The challengers are sharp, indomitable, and devious - and with each match-up, it is uncertain who will win the crown.

Each character comes with its own unique ability which may be used once per game and a color coded set of dice. A set of power cards and fortune cards, a fairy card and a die associated with said fairy comprise the contents of the game. To win, a player needs to obtain seven points worth of relics, and hold on to them until the beginning of their next turn.

link.value: Scary Tales: Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella
Scary Tales: Little Red vs. Pinocchio
Scary Tales: Prince Charming vs. Hansel

item.description: A horse racing game on a lithographed tin. Players roll marbles into indentations in the center of the lid, and move their magnetic horses the appropriate distance around the outer track.

From the box...

The Adult Jigsaw Crossword Puzzle Game

WUPS! is a game wherein some words of Anglo Saxon origin may be formed which are considered slang or vulgarisms. While it is the object of the game not to form such words, it frequently happens. These words may refer to body parts or body functions.

The game comprises a box containing a shelf with a round hole in it and a 36-piece jigsaw puzzle. The jigsaw puzzle has sixty four letter words on it in a crossword puzzle grid. Some of the words are repeats. The same sixty words are on each side of the puzzle and the puzzle is cut so that the words are divided in half. Many of the edge pieces may be interchanged and all of the interior pieces are interchangeable. The corner pieces are unique. As players take turns reassembling the puzzle with pieces chosen at random, some embarrassing words may be formed. The winner is the player who makes the fewest "naughty" words.

name.value: Bakugan Battle Brawlers Skill & Action Game

item.description:
Description: You and your opponents become the ultimate Battle Brawlers and must save the Bakugan that are trapped in Vestroia!

Release the Rods that trap them, and catch them as the plummet down to Earth!

Catch as many Bakugan Balls with the gaming scoops, be the first player to build your Gate Card puzzle and win!

Warning! Beware of Hydranoid.

Object of the Game: Be the first player to catch enough Bakugan Balls(Marbles) to complete your Gate Card Puzzle, 4 pieces.

Play Summary: One Player pull a rods out of Vestroia (the tower) which will release Bakugan Balls (Marbles). The players whose turn it is try to catch these Bakugan Balls with the two game scoops, if he catches the ball before it stops rolling the player gets a Puzzle piece for his Gate card puzzle. One of the Balls is the evil Hydranoid (the black marble), if you catch the Hydranoid you lose a gate piece. Scoops are passed clock wise and play continues until one of the players wins. When all size Marbles are released from the tower return all the rods and marbles and continue playing until you have a winner.

Not the CCG/CMG (Collectible Marble Game?) but a stand alone board game with a very similar title and theme.

HIJACK is a roll and move game, players are long haul truck drivers, picking up and dropping off loads at different cities in the US and Canada, making a living and avoiding HIJACK.

The board is a map of northern North America, part of Mexico is shown, but the paths between cities do not go there. Most cities have two or three paths leading to/from them, but some (Detroit, Jacksonville, New Orleans) only have one way in or out. Spaces on the paths reward or penalize players, moving your Big Rig back or forward spaces, rewarding your good deeds with cash, or fining you for speeding, for instance.

There are three decks of cards, Load, Partial Load, and Destination.

A pack of money, printed for the game.

There are 4 Trailer Title cards, 4 Truck Insurance cards, and 4 wooden Big Rigs, apparently cut out by a band saw.

There are also two other wooden pieces, I think these are tractors minus their trailers.

Professionally printed (it has a bar code), no designer, artist or publisher credits. No rules in the only copy I have found.

I have a copy of this game I found going through my archive. The publisher is LAD Game Company, PO Box 926, Salem, OR 97308. I suspect I purchased this new from my FLGS (which has been out of business for over 25 years). My copy only has 4 tractor pieces, no trailers.

UPDATE.

I know the person/people that made this game. I will update with instructions pictures to follow. I will also add different pictures showing actual game pieces in the coming days.

Card game from David Parlett played on 2 levels:

Aim of the game:

To place cards in a 4 x 4 grid in such a way as to avoid duplicating the suit of an adjacent card and the rank of a card in the same row or column. Any such match of suit or rank gives away points to one's opponent.

Ancestor of http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/7705 Zoo Party

The Game of Subtraction, Strategy and Fun!

Learn how to subtract numbers the Roll ’n Subtract fun way! It is easier than you think! Play with your friends while learning subtraction- challenge your friends while learning strategies.

Simply roll the dice, subtract the numbers, check your answer against the subtraction table, and start building a triangle. The real fun starts when you plan a strategy and capture your opponent’s playing pieces!

A Monopoly like game, where players try to gather as much money as possible during the game. Duration is variable, with players deciding at the start of the game what the criteria is for the game ending (amount of money, elapsed time etc.) A single track runs round the board with four off-shots (trade, car-trade, fishery and stock exchange) at each corner. Players can buy lots and build properties and inflation plays part in whether they can sell their properties with profit or not.

A trivia game based on the tv show Meistarinn (The Maestro). In the tv show, two participants are pitted against each other trying to win the grand prize. The game is for 2-4 players but uses similar rules as the tv show.

A single track game with 125 spaces, similar to The Game of Life, where start in childrens school and try to finish as college graduates the quickest. There are 25 special spaces that are similar to the Snake & Ladders game, where you can move forward or backwards.

From Wikipedia:

"Sueca is a 4 players game, that plays with two teams, partners sitting opposite from each other. It is played with 40 cards (remove the 8s, 9s, 10s from a standard 52 card deck). The rank of the cards in each suit, from highest rank to lowest one, is: Ace, 7, King, Jack, Queen, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2. As well as the high position of the seven, notice that the jack beats the queen..

The game is played clockwise. The first dealer is chosen at random and the turn to deal passes to the left after each hand.The player to the dealer's right shuffles the cards and the player at the dealer's left cuts. The dealer then gives 10 cards to each player, in a single batch, beginning with the player to dealer's left, going around clockwise and ending with the dealer. The bottom card of the deck, which belongs to the dealer, is turned face up, and its suit becomes trumps.Alternatively, the dealer can choose to deal the first ten cards to himself, the next ten to the player to his right, and so on counter-clockwise. In this case the dealer's first card (the original top card of the deck) is turned up and determines the trump suit.

The player to the left of the dealer (the one who cut the cards) leads to the first trick. Players must follow suit if they can. A player who has no card of the suit led may play any card. If any cards of the trump suit are played to a trick, the highest trump wins. Otherwise, the trick is won by the highest card of the suit led. The winner of each trick leads to the next.

Being considered a "deaf-dumb persons game" in Portugal, there can be no talking between the players and no exchange of signals between partners (considered cheating in tournament play). In casual play, though, this rule is frequently overridden, with signs actually being negotiated between partners prior to playing, which adds a different level of fun to the game - as each team tries to discover the others cheating signs so they can get the upper hand in play.

In Sueca, the aim is to win tricks containing valuable cards. The card values are:
Ace ..... 11 points
7 ..... 10 points
King ..... 4 points
Jack ..... 3 points
Queen ..... 2 points
The rest of the cards = no points.

There are 120 points in the deck altogether.

The object of the play is to win tricks containing more than half of the card points. The team which takes more than 60 card points scores one game. The first team to score four games win the rubber.

If a team takes 91 or more card points in tricks on one deal, they score two games instead of one.

If they take all the tricks they score four games and thus win the rubber immediately. Taking 120 points but losing a trick (with no counting cards in it) is not sufficient to win the rubber. In this case the winning team would just score 2 games for having more than 90.

In case of tie it's considered a null game... no team gets any point."

There is a variant called Sueca Italiana which is for 5 players.

item.description:
The game contains a playing board with four squares (countries!) depicted on it. Each country has 16 playing fields:

2 orange fields: an airport with international connections and a national airport
1 yellow field: holiday resort
9 red fields: pieces of land meant for the founding of companies
4 green fields: follow the instructions or directions

The game is similar to Monopoly.

Special Valentine's Day version of Scrabble. Comes in a box similar to a heart shaped box of chocolates. Contains smaller heart shaped board (kind of a blocky heart shape, since it is made of squares) and 100 Letter Tiles.

Play is like normal Scrabble, with the addition of a list of 12 romantic themed words, that if used, scores an additional 4 point bonus in addition to normal tile and grid space scoring.

Also included in the game are adhesive dots and a Scrabble and Valentine's Day themed greeting card, so that you could use some of the tiles to spell out a message on the greeting card for your loved one.

The history of mankind is just starting. First antecedents of man are entering the scene full of wild prehistoric plants and bizarre creatures. You are one of them, a leader of a large group of anthropoids. A mysterious force of evolution makes you grow, multi-play and evolve at surprisingly high speed. For a quick evolution you need a lot of meat so you focus on hunting mammoths. The more mammoths you hunt down, the more quickly your brain grows.
With a bigger brain you can do more things… You can improve your hunting skills and face your enemies more successfully. The best hunters will achieve the desired goal of evolution, becoming a modern human – and thus securing immortality of their species. Those less successful, whose development froze at a lower level of evolution, can at least go to have a chat with their relatives in a zoo.

Brief summary of the game, the goal and the end of the game:
The player determines by means of the cards of commands, where his pack should go. Packs go across the landscapes and they try to hunt down as many mammoths as possible (by going across cards with pictures of mammoths on them), so that they have proteins to grow their brains more quickly and to rise on the evolutionary meter. By doing this the skills of the pack will grow and evolutionary advantages can be acquired. The winner of the game is the person who will be the first to complete his evolution by reaching the level of a human homo-sapiens. At this moment the game ends.

Part of a series of "Yotta Know..." games on different topics, Yotta Know Mammals is a game played on a six-by-six grid board on which players place cards depicting mammals to be identified. The first player to identify seven mammals wins the round. Rolling dice adds a randomizing element to gameplay, while a handicap system allows players of varying knowledge levels to play against each other.
 The game uses a deck of 63 mammals, all of which are found in North America.
 Expanded by: 

 Yotta Know Birds
 Yotta Know Waterfowl

item.description:
A very early word card game. Its deck has 36 cards, all with letters except for two Blockade Cards, which just take up space in the hand without being usable. It also includes cardboard chits labeled "5 Points" or "10 Points"; some editions include a pocket dictionary. The rules describe five games:

Original Bild-A-Word: 5 cards each are dealt. In the first round, each player in turn lays 1-2 words of 2+ letters on the table, or adds letters to an existing word (rearranging if needed) to make a new word, or passes. From then on, a turn starts by drawing 1 card and ends with discarding 1 card; if the draw pile runs out, shuffle the discards to restock it. The hand ends when a player empties his hand, and he scores 5 points per cards held in others' hands -- the point chits are used to keep score. 250 points wins the game.

Bild-A-Word Triplets: Like the Original game, except that after the deal, 3 cards are placed in separate rows on the table. Players may not start new words, but only try to add to the existing rows to make new words. Letters may be rearranged within a row but not moved between rows.

Bild-A-Word Marathon: 8 cards are dealt to the table. In each turn, a player makes a word out of any 2 or more letters on the table. They may not repeat previous words, and have only 1 minute per turn. When a player is stumped they are out; the winner is the last player to come up with a word.

Bild-A-Word Wits: Like 5 card draw poker with words. Players start with 100 points worth of Point chits, and win on getting 300 points worth. Hands are ranked by the length of the words in them: 5 letters; 4; 3&2; 3; 2&2; 2. Ties are broken by the letters earliest in the alphabet.

Bild-A-Word Quinto: Like gin rummy. Players start with 5 cards, and in a turn draw 1 and discard 1. The first to make a 5-letter word from his hand calls "Quinto" and lays his hand down. All other players lay down their hands and make the longest word they can; the winner gets 5 point for each unused card. Game is 250.

Texas Hold-Em with words. The deck has 83 cards each with a letter and value of 1-8.

All start with an equal number of chips. There is a typical order: ante; deal 3 "hole" cards to each player; a round of betting; 2 "flop" cards face up in the middle; betting; 1 more face up (the "turn"); betting; 1 last card face up (the "river"); betting; the showdown. The players who haven't folded make their highest scoring word from their hole and the common cards; if a word has 6 letters, its value is doubled, if 7, it is tripled. Highest score wins the pot; if a tie, the pot is shared.

Players aim at the targets and try to knock them off the target either by simply rolling the marble or by using the thumb as in other marble games. Highest score wins. Game comes with 2 long wooden sections and 6 characters that are hung on the frame and serve as targets.

Maisy Lotto is a childrens lotto aimed at rather younger children than most lottos - with just 4 pictures per board, instead of the usual 9. This makes it an ideal starter lotto for younger children - in fact by the time they reach the 3+ range indicated on the box, they are probably too old for this and ready for regular childrens lotto games.

The pictures come from the popular Maisy stories, and the boards are brightly coloured red, blue, yellow and green.

A simple yet most enjoyable game for children Ages 4 - 8. 2-4 can play, or a child can amuse himself playing alone.

The pieces are placed face up in the centre of the table. Throw the coloured die in turn. If you throw white, you take a white front wall; if you throw any other colour before you possess your front wall you pass. Once you have this you take pieces that match the colour you throw. If you throw a colour you do not require, you pass. The first player to complete his house wins the game.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Which child will get the most swans?

The 9 swans start at one end of the board and each player chooses a child to be. In turn each player rolls the dice and moves along the track of the appropriate colour from lily pad to lily pad. If you roll purple you may move any swan one space. The aim is to move the swans on to the beach where your child is standing. When all swans have reached the beach the game ends and the player whose child has the most swans is the winner.

Fast little card and token game where you need to buy vegetable seeds at the market, grow them every turn and sell them for profit without the other players ruining it for you.
The player that manage his gold the better and get the most cash by the end of the year wins the game.

This is an astrological game, revolving around the twelve signs of the Zodiac. Based on the roll of a die, actions on the Astrocards and the player's purchases during the game, a personality description is finally constructed which fits each player. In addition the numbers that players purchase during the game decide the winner of the game.

The game consists of a dice cup like in Yahtzee, with 6 ordinary dice, a timer, a notepad and a pencil.

Players roll the 6 dice and then everyone must use all 6 numbers to reach a particular score before the timer runs out.

You start with 1, and move on progressively to 2, 3, and so forth until 10. The first player to successfully reach 10 wins the game.

Each of the 6 numbers must be used exactly once, and you may Add, Subtract, Multiply or Divide as you please!

When the time's up you check whose calculation is actually correct. This player moves on to the next target score. Everyone else must redo the score they just failed.

A spoof game about the so called 'Financial Vikings' of Iceland. The board is only 14 spaces (including the starting space) and players roll two die to get to space 13. If the player doesn't get 13 on the roll, he moves from space to space until he ends up on the beginning space again. If the player gets 13 he's done the impossible and won the game.

The title means "Crossword Puzzle Game", and it matches that description very closely. [The rules were in German, but I believe I have the gist of it.]

The game is for two players or teams. There are 2 decks of 60 cards, one red and one blue. Each has 45 letters and 15 blocks -- which show a checkerboard but stand for the filled-in squares between the words in an actual crossword puzzle.

Each side shuffles their letter cards and draws a hand of 10 cards. The first player lays out a word from their hand horizontally, places a block card at either end of the word, and draws back up to 10. The opponent then places a word vertically, using one of the existing letters as part of it, also capping its end with block cards. Play continues in this manner, one side doing horizontal words, the other vertical, forming a typical crossword. Only one word can be done per turn. A word may be lengthened instead, the block being removed and replaced at the end of the longer word. If a player cannot play he passes.

The game ends when a side runs out of cards, or neither side can make a new word. The winner is the one with the most cards played.

A word card game, whose deck has 85 cards, each with a letter and its value.

In the basic game, a player's turn consists of turning over 3 letters face up in order, and naming as many words as they can that contain those 3 letters in that order. Example: with PAT, you could name sPAT, PArT, sePAraTe, etc. Then the score is the sum of the cards' values time the number of words stated. There is a maximum of 5 words, and a time limit is recommended for the turns. If the player thinks no word is possible he declares a Stymie, and if no one else can think of a word he gets 100 points; if someone can, she gets 50 points while the declarer loses 50. After the deck runs out, highest total wins.

There are several variations:

1. Juniors - For younger players, use 2 cards instead.

2. Sliders - use 2 cards, and only 5-letter words with both letters adjacent are allowed, one each of XXxxx, xXXxx, xxXXx, and xxxXX.

3. Twos - Use 2 cards, and think of any number of words (up to ten), of any length, with both letters adjacent.

4. Famous Names - Use 2 cards, and try to think of a famous name with those initials.

5. Initials - Use 2 cards, and think of a phrase, or two related words, the begin with those two letters. (E.g., with MD, Medical Doctor.)

6. Solitaire - use 3 cards, and find only 1 word per triple; try to find one for each triple dealt.

7. Charades - Use 2 cards, and act out a phrase starting with those two letters.

There are two versions of Zombie in my Pocket, go to Zombie in my Pocket for the 1-player print and play version.

The semi-cooperative 1-8 player published version (from Cambridge Games Factory). The game offers players chances to help the group, or play selfishly, and you never know what your fellow zombie bashers are going to do.

In Zombie in my Pocket, you're searching for the secret of the evil temple where you can find the item to destroy the zombies rising from the dead. You can pick up items to bash zombies along the way; a machete, golf club, chain saw, or even your former uncle's grisly femur.

Find the zombie totem, then bury it in the backyard graveyard before midnight and you've saved the world. Otherwise, you're zombie food.

link.value: Zombie in my Pocket: Masque maya

item.description:
The game is called Making Money, and the goal as you can imagine is to make as much money as you can, anyway you can. This is done by moving around the streets of a city while buying up and developing property. Money can also be made by buying and selling stocks that go up and down in value.

While the game involves some chance from drawing cards and rolling dice, without a good strategy you will quickly find yourself well on your way to financial ruin. The game is very easy to learn and during play testing has been a lot of fun! To win the game, simply keep making money while trying to stay ahead of everyone else. The game is played for a set number of rounds and the player with the most money at the end wins.

I welcome everyone and anyone to jump in, give feedback, and play test if you can. Play testing takes place in New York City, upcoming dates and locations can be found on our website, link is below in this listing.

First published as part of the Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1 anthology as Rollende Steine, Rolling Rocks is sort of a tabletop, Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game golf. The players act as a team of Celtic giants, entertaining themselves by rolling rocks through the trilithons. The method by which she rolls her stone each turn is entirely up to the player, be it flicking, using a stick for leverage, or even blowing on it. In addition to the dexterity element, players are granted the opportunity to place and move sticks on the board in order to attempt to guide their wayward stones.

This is a quasi-word game that is unique in several aspects: the words used are personal names; the cards stand only for vowels; everyone is working on the same word at once.

It has a 52-card deck, each of which has a vowel (AEIOU) or semi-vowel (WY), a number value, and a list of names that use that vowel. The 52nd card, though, is a Substitute card which can stand for any vowel.

Seven cards are dealt to each player. On his turn a player declares and spells a personal name, and then everyone must discard the vowels in that name. For example, if he says "Andrew", everyone in turn must discard an A card, then each must discard an E, then each must discard a W. Any player who cannot discard the current letter must draw from the draw pile, and discard it if it's the right letter, or keep it if not. The discard pile is reshuffled to replenish the draw pile, if needed.

A player goes out on playing his last card in hand, except that the caller cannot go out until the name he called is finished. When a hand is over, each player scores the sum of the cards still in hand. Play until someone reaches an agreed total, at which point the lowest total wins.

First published as part of the Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1 anthology as Der Hohe Rat, The High Council is a political game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game. Each faction vies to form a contiguous block (comprising speakers and supporters) in the council of 16 seats. This constitutes a contiguous majority - a mighty force.

First published as part of the Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1 anthology as Erbaut Stonehenge!, A Grand Endeavor has seen subsequent development. (For example, as originally published, it was for 3-4 players.) This Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game game focuses on the actual construction of Stonehenge. In each player's turn, she has a construction phase, a draw phase, and a commit phase during which she may commit to a project. There is opportunity for spite in A Grand Endeavor, as a player may choose to defame another faction's character, setting that player back a little. Once Stonehenge is completely constructed, the game ends, and players are awarded points for their works, with some bonus points for adjacency.

First published as part of the Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1 anthology as Trilithen Knallen is a demolition derby amongst druids, staged at Stonehenge. This unusual Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game game is most certainly an elimination game, as druids attempt to deal as much damage as possible while staying in the race.

First published as part of the Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1 anthology as Opferroulette, Sacrifice Roulette is an official Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game game of luck. Players essentially bet on priests, which are gradually eliminated through the course of the game by a roulette-style mechanism.

This is a collection of three card games and a tray to play them in. The cards are square and of thick cardstock. The plastic tray has 3x3 playing area of recessed squares -- to allow stacking while preventing slippage ("great car fun") -- and a deeper square to the side for the draw pile.

Each game has its own small deck:

1. Wiggle Worm: There are 2 head cards that start at opposite corners; the rest of the cards show parts of one or two worm bodies that pass through the card. A connection game.

2. Cross Word: Each card has a letter. Players try to spell words across and down, and perhaps diagonally.

3. Tick-Tack Whoa: The cards show either X, O, or "Whoa".

name.value: Last Gamble: The Battle of the Bulge

item.description:
Last Gamble: The Battle of the Bulge is a division-level game covering the first two weeks of the battle in the Ardennes Forest in December, 1944. The game system is based on DDH Games' successful June '44.

Components include:

1 12-page full-color rulebook
1 11 x 17" Map
1 sheet of 120 die-cut counters
1 Player Aid Card
1 Game Track Card
1 10-sided die
24 event cards

The game is fast playing and highly competitive, but very easy to learn and suitable for beginning wargamers. It's also very suitable for solo play.

item.description:
It's fun, it's exciting & most of all it's unlike any other game you've played!!!
Traveling along the tracks you'll need to be vigilant at all times. Countless names but only seconds to say one, how quick can you think?
Keep your wits about you, collect all your passengers & deliver them safely to the central station. Watch out though, your opponents could steal them at anytime!
It's more about who you know, than what you know! Just roll the dice...Land on a category (films, well known people, actors & actresses, sports people, t.v. programs or music)....Say a valid name in 30 seconds. Simple!!!
For example, it's your turn, the player to your right has just said "George Michael" (they were on a music square). You roll the dice, move four spaces & land on a T.V. square....you now have 30 seconds to say the name of a T.V.program that begins with the last letter of the previous answer, 'L'.

This trivia game is concentrated on the authors hometown in Iceland, Vopnafjörður. Includes a board with a spiraling track from the edge inwards. Three types of cards are included; questions (players get the card if they answer correctly), information (informative text only) and opportunity (both good and bad). Players progress along the track by the roll of a die.

A chess variant designed in 1967 by an Icelandic carpenter. Played on a grid of 85 hexagonal spaces, in 9 rows, the spaces being in three colours. There are 18 white and 18 black pieces which are the same as in traditional chess with one new type, the viking, which starts between the king and the queen. The pieces move in the same way as in traditional chess (more or less).

In Power, each player is an individual character who ages, has a job, may get married, have children (who turn into additional characters), start factories, etc. All of this is controlled by playing cards on your own or other characters. Characters also have levels, which may be gained in various ways, including accumulating certain large amounts of money.

The object is to have the last living character. This may be accomplished by outliving the other characters, as characters of low level automatically die at age 70 (although if they have children, their players are still in the game). It is also possible to kill other characters, either by using certain cards or by being enough levels above them. An alternative way to win is to reach the sixth level.

A set collection game (Memory), where players try to collect sets of four famous persons from Icelandic history. There are 60 cards in 15 categories included. The cards include text and pictures of the persons.

Box blurb:

"ADVENTURE GAME STARTER SETS are a complete introduction to the hobby of Fantasy Adventure Gaming, all in one box. Each ADVENTURE GAME STARTER SET contains ten paintable plastic action figures in the standard 25mm size, a set of non-toxic water-based paints with instructions and brush, and a complete set of fast, playable rules for playing out your own fantasy adventures. Even the gaming die is included. (For two or more players, ages 10 and up)."

Four were published:

The Wizard's Bane

The Cleric's Quest - "the adventures of a young cleric (holy man or woman) as he (or she) dons armor and weapons to fulfill a holy quest - a journey which brings him (or her) into combat with animated Skeletons, a pair of Hell hounds, a female Demon, and a fearsome Devil."

The Fighter's Fury - "the adventures of a young knight and his friend as they do battle with Goblins, foul Orcs, a huge Troll, and an evil Baron in a quest to avenge the death of the young knight's father."

The Woman Warrior - "the adventures of a young woman warrior and her friend as they do battle with Bandits, Kobolds (small fierce dog like creatures), giant Bugbears, and a huge fearsome Ogre, in a quest for treasure and glory."

Each contains two leaflets, one containing the rules and adventure; the other, a painting guide for the miniatures. Though each game has a unique background story and series of encounters, the rules of play are identical. On the last page of the rules leaflet is a promotion for Heritage's soon-to-be-released (at that time) RPG, Swordbearer.

Gameplay consists of running two characters through a series of four encounters (combats). Each side in a combat takes turns. During a turn, all characters on the active side fight, then all characters on the active side may use magic, pick up or throw things, or run away.

Fighting is resolved by cross-indexing the roll of a six-sided die with the letter code of the attacker's weapon (A, B, C or D) on a table corresponding to the defender's armor (which may be light, medium, or heavy) in order to find how much damage, if any, was done to the defender.

The miniatures aren't necessary to play, and aren't even mentioned in the game rules.

A Bible-oriented word card game. The deck has 52 letter cards and 2 wild cards, with values ranging from 2 to 20 points -- the rarer, the higher.

Deal 10 cards each if 2 play, 7 if 3 or 4, 6 cards if 5 or 6 play. In a turn, a player draws the top of the draw or discard pile, lays down a word or adds to an existing word or name from the Bible, and discards a card. They may also replace a wild card on the table with the letter it is currently standing for, from their hand.

The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the hand and its points. Each word's score is the sum of its cards' values; proper names from the Bible are doubled. If a player plays all their hand in one turn, their total for the hand is doubled. Play until reaching an agreed number of points or hands.

Novar Cottage also published a different version called Alphacard Word Rummy. The rules are identical except they don't mention Bible names as acceptable words.

item.description:
Huddle is a game played while watching an American football game on television. Each player's pawn is a football helmet which is placed on the board to indicate a prediction about what will happen on the next play. At the same time each player wagers chips to the center of board. Based on the outcome of the play, the chips wagered are taken by one or more of the players. Play continues until one player has won all the chips.

Components: Board, 4 Helmets, Chips, Rules

name.value: Dora the Explorer Follow the Leader

item.description:
This is a simple children's game in which players flip a coin to determine if they move one or two spaces. On each space they must complete a simple activity, for instance "Flap Your Arms" and "Blink Your Eyes." Each player who is behind the leader must also complete this physical activity. Like most roll-and-move children's games, the first player to the final space wins.

This game was first published in Nick Jr. Magazine cover date April 2009.

PGH-4 is played on a 4x4 board with two players. The goal of the game is to get your 4 pieces in a row, either horizontally, vertically or diagonally. Players alternate taking turns adding one of their pieces on the board from any of the 16 edges of the board. If a piece (of either player) already exists there, it is pushed forward in the same direction, possibly pushing another piece and so on. Pieces can fall of the board this way in which case it's returned to its owner. If a piece fell of the board, a move immediately in the absolute opposite direction is forbidden.

Big Rock Candy Mountain is a game for 2-5 players. Each player controls a miniature hobo (from now on referred to as a meebo). The players have their meebos hop trains in order to move around the U.S. to find work. When a meebo works it collects dimes. These dimes are than cashed in at a hobo jungle to throw a ho-down and increase the meebos reputation. Watch out for the bull (train yard cop) he'll take all of a meebos money! The first hobo to become famous (or infamous) across the country is titled king/queen of the hobos and can retire at Big Rock Candy Mountain.

name.value: Grand Prix Auto Race Game by Jackie Stewart

item.description:
This is a fairly simple racing game in the general mold of Speed Circuit. Each car is a (randomly-generated) mix of maximum acceleration, maximum deceleration, top speed, and braking ability. Speeds for each turn are written simultaneously on the included record sheets. Curves have maximum posted speeds, but also have "apex lines" through them which, if followed precisely, allow one to go faster.

The above description is of the "advanced" game. The beginner's game is a simple roll-and-move exercise. There is also a "super advanced" game which adds rules for slip-streaming, blocking, etc.

This game was one of six in RGI's Play the Pros series.

A significantly modified version of the game is included as part of Sports Spectacular.

link.value: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

name.value: Pro Tennis Game by Rod Laver

item.description:
This is a simple singles tennis game. In the beginner's game, after rolling a single die for the serve, players alternate rolling a pair of dice to get one of 21 possibilities for their shot, continuing until one is missed. In the advanced game, court position is taken into account, and players each get a special weakness card, but all the action is still driven by the dice.

The game was one of six in RGI's Play the Pros series.

A significantly modified version of this game was published as part of Sports Spectacular.

link.value: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

item.description: Players hold cards valued 1,2,3,4,7,8,9,10. These are placed in the middle (one per player per turn), the numbers are added up. A player that can reach 55,66,77,88 or 99 gets a point, the player who breaks 111 gets 5 points. Whoever has most points after 5 rounds, wins. This game was part of Piatnik's 1989 Texas Series.

"The Award Winning Souvenir Game" in English & Gaeilige!
The aim of the game is to be the player with the most money at the end of the shift ... if you survive the shift!
The players are taxi drivers collecting money (pound and euro) by moving from destination to destination using dice.

A privately-produced word card game that has the rare attribute of only having rules for solitaire play.

There are 88 letter cards in the deck. They are dealt into 3 rows of 4 cards each. At each "turn", make a word from the cards in one row only -- each word must have at least 3 letters, but they don't have to be used in the order they are placed in their row. Remove the word just made from the layout, then replace the cards used with new cards from the deck, and add an extra card at the end of the two rows not used for the word. After the whole deck is dealt out, you may make words from the entire layout, not just from one row.

If at any point you cannot make a word when you need to, you lose. If you use up the entire deck with words, you achieve a Baby Slam. If you use up the deck while always making words from one row only, you achieve a Grand Slam.

From the box cover:

"Bolero - a tactical game for two.

A rousing, ingeniously simple game, where winning demands all your acuity and maneuvering skills."

Players take turns to place their markers on the board. Both players have 64 markers numbered 1-4, 16 of each. The board is a 4x4 grid of 2x2 squares numbered 1-4. The played marker always goes to a square with a same number.

The player who first creates

1. a row of 4 same numbers horizontally, vertically or diagonally,

2. a row of 4 different numbers horizontally, vertically or diagonally or

3. a 2x2 square of 4 different numbers

with his own markers wins the game.

item.description: A simple but fun word game, using three colourful dice and an hourglass. Flip the hourglass and roll the first die, which determines the colour or can give zero or ten points without using the other two dice. The second die determines the starting letter and the third die determines the word length.

Delivery is a fast-paced, fast-food game where players compete for orders and try to deliver them on time.
So simple it barely requires dice and cash, Delivery is an easy to learn game with tough competition and fun variables: Will your restaurant be cheap or expensive? Will you invest in publicity or food quality? Will you make it on time and receive a generous tip or will your delivery boy be too slow and arrive too late?
Build your fast-food empire by building more and more restaurants and crushing your opponents.

You can choose to play with any of the following restaurant types:
Chinese
Italian
Mexican
Japanese
Indian
American

These adorable little mischievous puppies will delight young children and their parents. The puppies have each got a corner of the tablecloth and just won't let go! Players try to make a full burger by stacking up all the trimmings as the playful pups tug the cloth to make the burgers wobble and fall apart. The player with the fullest burger when the time is up gets a bone.

Contents: Electronic Table Base, 16 Dog Bones, 16 Filling Discs, 4 Burger Bun Bases, 4 Burger Bun Lids, Ketchup Bottle Start Button, Table Top, 4 Puppies and Instructions

St Gert’s is under threat! The Ministry is trying to close the 'Naughtiest Girl’s School in all England'. Ministry Spies are disguised as various members of staff, pupils and auxiliary staff and if you don’t find them quickly then Old Gerty will close her hallowed doors forever! House captains, it is up to you to root out these insidious goodie-goodies and SAVE THE SCHOOL!

… unless of course you are secretly working for the ministry... then it is your duty to the Minister and the crown to wipe that so called educational establishment from off the map!

In this partially co-operative game players play actions and vote to eliminate one character from the school each round in an attempt to fulfil their various Hidden agendas and the wider game goal of saving the school (or not!). Influence within the school is won and lost during play making the characters in your House Team more or less powerful when it comes down to the vote.

Suspicion is high in the halls and cloisters of St Gert’s…use that to your advantage.

name.value: The Best of GDW's Harpoon Sitrep

item.description:
From the publisher´s webpage

Due to the success of the reprinting the old GDW Naval SitReps, Clash of Arms Games decided to issue a compilation of the articles and scenarios from the old GDW SitReps. It is a 64 pages booklet

The following articles appear:

* A Naval Perspective on Nuclear Weapons Effects
 * Attacking Offshore Oil Platforms
 * Radar Countermeasures for the Wargamer
 * Standing Orders
 * Hard Times for the Royal Navy
 * Aegis and US Missile Systems
 * The Dawn of Missile Warfare
 * Ship Fuel Capacities (for Logistics Article also in the book)
 * Tomahawk Loadouts for US Ships
 * Soviet Aircraft Tactics
 * Submarine Propulsors
 * The Other Navy
 * U.S. Navy Composite Warfare Doctrine
 * The Tactical Air-Launched Decoy
 * Royal Navy Traditional Toasts
 * Clearing Storm - Changes in the Soviet Navy
 * Russian Revelations
 * Photo: The Collapse of the Red Navy
 * Keep Your Eyes on the Dragon
 * Uncertain Weapon
 * Submarine Communications
 * Logistics

The following Scenarios appear (with current Data):

* Mediterranean Melee
 * Halifax Convoy
 * Red War
 * Fast Convoy
 * The Last Exocet

The following Kitbash Corner models are included:

* Part 1 and Krivak III
 * Part 2 and Nanuchka II
 * Updating Long Beach
 * Canadian TRUMP conversion
 * Converting Kirov to Frunze
 * Upgrading Atlantic Conveyor For Harrier Operations
 * Chilean Latorre and Blanco Encaldo

The following book reviews are included:

* The Boats of Cherbourg
 * The Royal Navy and the Falklands War
 * Falklands the Air War
 * MiG "A History of the Design Bureau"
 * Encyclopedia of Aircraft Armament
 * U.S. Nuclear Weapons: the Secret History
 * Fighter Aircraft
 * F-86 Sabre
 * The Art of Wargaming
 * Squadron in Action Series
 * One Hundred Days
 * Antisubmarine Warfare
 * Sub vs. Sub

Naval Thunder: Clash of Dreadnoughts is an exciting, fast paced miniatures game of World War I naval combat. Its first in an exciting line of naval wargames from Steel Dreadnought Games and is designed for use with miniatures of scales 1/1800 - 1/6000. Newcomers will appreciate how straight-forward and easy to learn the basic system is, while naval wargaming veterans can take advantage of the optional rule system to add additional detail to the game.

NT: CoD has been designed from the keel up to be fun, fast paced, and full of flavor so that you can focus on the thrill of commanding a ship or fleet at sea instead of tedious charts or calculations. A battle involving a dozen battleships and battlecruisers on each side can be fought to a conclusion in a couple hours while offering a play experience with significant tactical depth.

The robust optional rules system allows the game to grow with you as you gain experience - ensuring that Naval Thunder will be your naval miniatures system of choice for years to come. There are more than 20 completely modular optional rules that allow you to model historically accurate factors influencing naval combat of the era. You can pick and choose which rules to include allowing you to tailor the pace of play and level of detail to your personal preference.

Just a few examples of the kinds of historically accurate details you can add to the game include:


 Poor design of British shells causing them to shatter on striking heavy armor
 Poor cordite flash precautions
 The impact of historical commanders
 Crew training levels
 The influence of wind direction on gunnery
 Using submarines to soften up your opponent's battlefleet


Optional shortcuts allow you to use Naval Thunder: Clash of Dreadnoughts to run huge fleet actions such as Jutland in a fraction of time other non-abstract systems would take.

Included with the rules are data cards for 80 classes of ship, representing hundreds of historical vessels, allowing you to model nearly any action between the Royal Navy and Kaiserliche Marine during the first world war.

item.description:
Nineteen is played on a 3×3 hexagonal board. The board is occupied by stones.

On each turn, each player must do one of the following actions:


 Remove one stone
 Remove two adjacent stones
 Remove three stone forming a triangle


The player that removes the last stone loses.

item.description:
CONQUER, Home Island Hawaiian war card game.

From the Box

Ages 7 and up
2 to 4 players.

Example in photo shows an actual deck with some card examples. The game itself revolves around ancient Hawaii as players battle to control an island. Card types include warriors, chiefs, divine intervention, priests, and more. 50 cards per pack plus instruction cards in both English and Japanese.

The gameplay is basically a more strategic version of war, with special abilities and multiple battles resolved at once.

The goal in Cirkle Kids is to collect a set of 4 shapes or 4 colors pieces. the board is formed of 16 squares covered by 16 gray hats -Magician style hat- , the challenge is to be able to remember which symbol is under the hat you just uncovered. The roll of dice and the possibility of rotating the board add a mix of luck/strategy to the game .
The game is the most simple to play (billed as kids) in the Cirkle board games family.
The object of the game is to be the first person to win $10,000 and 10 Blue Ribbons. The game is based on real live events at a horse show.

This is a Lotto variant. In the basic version, it is just regular Lotto with pictures of endangered animals. In a variant, players need to answer some quiz questions about the animals if they want to score a point (get a card).
